title: Using Redshifts to Determine Galaxy Recessional Velocities

next.title: Gathering the Data for a Hubble Plot - Galaxy 1

content:
Rubin Observatory measures the brightness of a galaxy through multiple filters over a range of wavelengths. The galaxy's light through different filters is then compared to a set of models to determine how much the galaxy's light has been shifted to longer wavelengths, or redshifted. This technique produces a redshift value that is referred to as photometric redshift (Z). A mathematical relationship is then used to calculate the recessional velocity (v) of the galaxy from its photometric redshift (Z). The larger the galaxyâ€™s photometric redshift, the faster the galaxy appears to be moving away from us.

Using this technique, Rubin Observatory will make a dramatic increase in the amount of redshift data for faint galaxies beyond what has previously been collected.
